snippet: In its biggest push ever into the hardware business, Microsoft unveiled a tablet computer called Surface that it intends to challenge Apple’s iPad.

headline.main: Microsoft Introduces a Challenger to the iPad
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Introduces A Challenger To the iPad

snippet: The tablet Microsoft showed off on Monday was a consumer product. There is another version, designed for professional use. A comparison of this machine, along with the iPad and a couple of lightweight laptops, show Microsoft is heading into its al...
abstract: The tablet Microsoft showed off on Monday was a consumer product. There is another version, designed for professional use. A comparison of this machine, along with the iPad and a couple of lightweight laptops, show Microsoft is heading into its allies' turf.

snippet: Sales at physical electronics stores have declined an average of 2.6 percent a year in the last five years, while sales online have risen an average of 14.7 percent a year in that period.
abstract: People are increasingly buying electronics online, even if they go to stores to examine product features; sales at physical electronics stores, like Best Buy, which has been particularly hit by the trend, have declined an average of 2.6 percent a year in the last five years, while sales online have risen 14.7 percent a year in that period.

headline.main: Electronics Retailers Scramble to Adapt to Changing Market

snippet: Surface is not just an iPad competitor. It's an ultrabook competitor. Microsoft seems to be going after a broader market than Apple does with its iPad. Microsoft is aiming at people who do work on laptops but want something even lighter.
abstract: Surface is not just an iPad competitor. It's an ultrabook competitor. Microsoft seems to be going after a broader market than Apple does with its iPad. Microsoft is aiming at people who do work on laptops but want something even lighter.

headline.main: Microsoft's Not Competing With the iPad — Not Entirely

snippet: After an eight-month tenure in which he oversaw a new marketing approach, Michael Francis is leaving the retailer.
abstract: J C Penney president Michael R Francis leaves after eight months.

headline.main: Penney’s No. 2 Executive Is Departing After 8 Months as President of Struggling Retailer
headline.print_headline: Penney’s No. 2 Executive Is Departing After 8 Months as President of Struggling Retailer

snippet: Apple’s mobile maps looks terribly light on information by contrast to Google maps although it is not the final product. Apple skinned data off the maps it showed developers. The question is, why?
abstract: Apple’s mobile maps looks terribly light on information by contrast to Google maps although it is not the final product. Apple skinned data off the maps it showed developers. The question is, why?

headline.main: Apple's Maps Don't Look So Bad

snippet: Sonos, which makes home audio equipment for listening to digital music, is raising $135 million from a group of investors that includes a couple of former Apple executives.
abstract: Sonos, which makes home audio equipment for listening to digital music, is raising $135 million from a group of investors that includes a couple of former Apple executives.

headline.main: Sonos Gets Boost From Former Apple Executives and Other Investors

snippet: John A. Quelch, co-author of “All Business Is Local: Why Place Matters More Than Ever in a Global, Virtual World,” says businesses need to localize, adapt and tailor their marketing decisions.
abstract: John A. Quelch, co-author of “All Business Is Local: Why Place Matters More Than Ever in a Global, Virtual World,” says businesses need to localize, adapt and tailor their marketing decisions.

headline.main: How Global Companies Take Aim at China

snippet: Couch seats on planes, Greece's social media campaign and more in our daily capsule of travel news.
abstract: Couch seats on planes, Greece's social media campaign and more in our daily capsule of travel news.

headline.main: Morning Walkabout -- 6/18: Couch Seats on Planes and Greece Beckons Tourists

snippet: Last week, Apple announced that its phones would no longer come with maps from Google built in, but instead would feature Apple's own map service, part of its new mobile operating system. In Monday's New York Times, Quentin Hardy looks into whethe...
abstract: Last week, Apple announced that its phones would no longer come with maps from Google built in, but instead would feature Apple's own map service, part of its new mobile operating system. In Monday's New York Times, Quentin Hardy looks into whether Apple can build a map service that does as good a job as Google's -- or a better one.

headline.main: Daily Report: Apple Takes On Google in Maps
